qas.question: Animal taste and smell rely on what kind of communication?
What is the physiological response of a sense organ called?
Chemical stimuli are signals that regulate the activity of what?
What is a message-carrying chemical called?
Kairomones are a type of what?

context: <a0_0>Chemical<a0_0/> communications in animals rely on a variety of aspects including taste and smell. <a1_0>Chemoreception<a1_0/> is the physiological response of a sense organ (i.e. taste or smell) to a chemical stimulus where the chemicals act as signals to regulate the state or activity of <a2_0>a cell<a2_0/>. A <a3_0>semiochemical<a3_0/> is a message-carrying chemical that is meant to attract, repel, and convey information. Types of <a4_0>semiochemicals<a4_0/> include pheromones and kairomones. One example is the butterfly Phengaris arion which uses chemical signals as a form of mimicry to aid in predation.
